ORDER: IT IS ORDERED that Plaintiffs' Motion to Permit Discovery During Administrative Stay (Doc. 219) is GRANTED. The Court agrees with Plaintiffs that allowing discovery to proceed will aid in the disposition of this case generally and the certification issue in particular, especially in light of the new evidence adduced at the certification hearing and related to the DOJ report. Moreover, the prejudice to Plaintiffs in being denied discovery during this time outweighs any prejudice to Defendants, particularly considering the facts (1) that the Fifth Circuit denied rehearing en banc in McNeal, and (2) that it is unlikely the Supreme Court will grant certiorari after it previously denied it for Crittindon. Accordingly, the administrative stay will be LIFTED for the limited purpose of allowing the parties to engage in post-certification hearing discovery. Any objections to specific discovery responses should be resolved first through Rule 37 discussions and then through a motion to be taken up by the Magistrate Judge in the first instance. If the parties desire a more formal schedule for discovery during the stay, they should confer in an attempt to amicably generate one. Should that fail, they can file a motion seeking same to be taken up by the Magistrate Judge. Signed by Judge John W. deGravelles on 04/19/2024. (This is a TEXT ENTRY ONLY. case_data.name: Humphrey v. LeBlanc
case_data.plaintiff_description: All persons remanded to Louisiana DOC's custody who were entitled to immediate release but were not for more than 48 hours.

related_cases.name: CRIPA Investigation of Louisiana Department of Public Safety and Corrections

case_data.summary:
This entry includes two putative class action lawsuits challenging Louisiana's alleged practice of detaining prisoners longer than necessary after those prisoners receive "time-served" sentences.

In Humphrey v. LeBlanc, on April 15, 2020, three former prisoners filed a putative class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Louisiana. Represented by the civil rights firm Loevy & Loevy, local counsel, and the Promise of Justice Initiative, a public interest group, the plaintiffs sued the Secretary of the Louisiana Department of Public Safety and Corrections (DOC), under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 and Louisiana state law. The plaintiffs sought compensatory and punitive damages for their alleged over-detentions.

All three named plaintiffs received sentences that were already complete upon sentencing due to the time they had already served prior to conviction. However, all three were held in DOC custody for weeks after their sentencing due to slow processing. Plaintiffs alleged that this constituted an illegal depravation of freedom under the 14th Amendment's due process clause. Moreover, plaintiffs alleged that the DOC has subjected "thousands" of criminal defendants in like situations to similar unlawful imprisonments and that the department's Secretary was "deliberately indifferent" to these alleged violations.

The case was assigned to U.S. District Judge John Wheadon deGravelles, sitting in Baton Rouge, LA. 

On December 3, 2020, seemingly prompted by this lawsuit, the U.S. Department of Justice launched an investigation under the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act into Louisiana's prisoner release practices.

After various discovery disputes, the plaintiffs filed their motion to certify class on July 21, 2022. The proposed class was: “all persons who have been remanded to the custody of the DOC since April 16, 2019, and who were entitled to release at the time of their remand (either pursuant to sentencing or parole revocation), but who were released by the DOC more than 48 hours past the time that they were remanded to the DOC’s custody.”

On January 25, 2023, the Department of Justice issued its report, finding that from January 2022 to April 2022, 27 percent of the people who were legally entitled to be released from state custody, some for minor crimes or first-time offenses, were held past their release dates. About 24 percent of those improperly detained had been held 90 days or longer past their release dates. The Department of Justice found that these violations of people’s due process rights were “severe, systemic, and [were] both caused and perpetuated by serious ongoing deficiencies in LDOC’s policies and practices.”

On February 28, 2023, the parties met with the Court for a status conference regarding the DOJ report, but the parties declined to hold a settlement conference. The parties continued to engage in discovery. 

Giroir v. LeBlanc was a similar putative class action lawsuit filed on February 19, 2021 in the U.S. District Court in the Middle District of Louisiana by one of the plaintiffs in Humphrey, represented by the same counsel. The Giroir plaintiff raised the same claims as the Humphrey plaintiffs, but sought declaratory and injunctive relief instead of monetary relief. Giroir was also assigned to Judge deGravelles. On May 5, 2021, Judge deGravelles agreed to consolidate the two cases (Humphrey v. LeBlanc and Giroir v. LeBlanc) for discovery purposes only. 

The defendants in Giroir moved to dismiss on April 9, 2021. The court ruled on the motion on March 30 of the following year, granting it in part and denying it in part. The court dismissed any claims from proposed class members sentenced prior to February 17, 2020 because they were barred by the statute of limitations. However, the court denied the motion to dismiss the claim for injunctive relief because the plaintiff had alleged enough facts to support that claim. 2022 WL 969614.

As of December 25, 2023, the cases were ongoing, with motions to certify the class pending in both.
case_data.summary_short: In 2020, three former Louisiana inmates filed this putative class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court in the Middle District of Louisiana. Plaintiffs claimed that their over-detentions and the over-detentions of thousands of other former inmates due to slow processing constituted a violation of their 14th Amendment right to due process and that the secretary of the Louisiana Department of Public Safety and Corrections was deliberately indifferent to these violations. The case was consolidated with a similar case for discovery. In January 2023, the U.S. Department of Justice released a report concluding that Louisiana frequently violated the due process rights of inmates through over-detention. As of December 2023, the cases were still in discovery and the plaintiffs' classes had not yet been certified.
case_data.summary_tiny: This damages action challenges alleged over-detention of thousands of Louisiana prisoners in federal court.   It's pending.

documents.title: Amended Class Action Complaint
documents.text:
Case 3:21-cv-00108-JWD-SDJ     Document 46    04/27/22   Page 1 of 21
 
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
MIDDLE DISTRICT OF LOUISIANA 
JOEL GIROIR, on behalf of himself and all   
similarly situated individuals,     
       
Plaintiff,  CIVIL ACTION NO. 21-cv-108 
   
v.  CLASS ACTION 
   
JAMES LEBLANC, in his official capacity as   
Secretary  of  the  Louisiana  Department  of  JURY TRIAL DEMANDED 
Public Safety & Corrections; and   
THE  LOUISIANA  DEPARTMENT  OF   
PUBLIC SAFETY & CORRECTIONS,   
 
Defendants. 
 
 
AMENDED CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT 
INTRODUCTION 
1.  For years now, the Louisiana Department of Public Safety & Corrections (โthe 
DOCโ) has been unlawfully and knowingly overdetaining thousands of Louisiana residents in its 
custody  every  year.  Defendant  James  LeBlanc,  Secretary  of  the  DOC,  has  known  about  this 
misconduct since at least 2012. Ex. 1, Dep. of Secretary LeBlanc at 45, 48-49. Secretary LeBlanc has 
admitted that the DOC is โlegally boundโ to release people on time, and he has admitted that the 
DOCโs chronic, unlawful overdetention is a โbig problem.โ Id. at 41. Yet the DOC has done little to 
fix this big problem, continuing to overdetain people as a matter of routine practice. 
2.  Many of these people are sentenced by a court to โtime servedโ or an equivalent 
sentence that legally entitles them to immediate release from the moment they are sentenced. But 
they are not immediately released. Instead, as a standard practice, the DOC delays computation of 
release dates and, in the meantime, simply continues to detain people who should be free. Many are 
forced to sit for weeks or even months with no idea of when the DOC will get around to processing 
their paperwork and releasing them. The DOC, in other words, falsely imprisons thousands of 
1 

Case 3:21-cv-00108-JWD-SDJ     Document 46    04/27/22   Page 2 of 21
 
people every year, upending lives, imposing punishment that no court has ordered, and creating 
uncertainty and misery for families across the state.  
3.  Still, Secretary LeBlanc has not implemented any policy to ensure that the DOC 
stops overdetainingโand falsely imprisoningโLouisianans. The DOC overdetains so many people 
that the DOC itself estimated that housing alone costs the state an extra $2.8M per year, Ex. 2, 
DOC Grant Application at 4, but Secretary LeBlanc has not attempted to reallocate that spending 
toward new measures to prevent the DOC from holding people past their legal release dates. 
4.  Named Plaintiff Joel Giroir is a victim of the DOCโs misconduct. He seeks to 
represent a Class of all persons who were sentenced to the custody of the Louisiana DOC on or 
since February 17, 2020, or who will be sentenced to the custody of the DOC in the future, and who 
were, or will be, entitled to release at the time of their sentencing, but who nevertheless remain in 
custody, now or in the future, for more than 48 hours past their sentencing dates. On behalf of the 
numerous people subject to this unlawful practice, Mr. Giroir seeks injunctive and declaratory relief 
against this false and unlawful overdetention.  
JURISDICTION AND VENUE 
5.  This Court has jurisdiction over Plaintiffโs federal claims pursuant to 28 U.S.C. ยงยง 
1331 and 1343(a). It has jurisdiction over Plaintiffโs state law claims pursuant to 28 U.S.C. ยง 1367 
because those claims arise from the same events and are part of the same case and controversy as 
the federal claims.  
6.  Venue is proper in this district under 28 U.S.C. ยง 1391. 
2 

Case 3:21-cv-00108-JWD-SDJ     Document 46    04/27/22   Page 3 of 21
 
PARTIES 
7.  Plaintiff Joel Giroir was eligible for immediate release upon his resentencing on 
January 26, 2021, but the DOC has not yet released him from custody.1 He is currently being heldโ
illegallyโat St. Tammany Parish Jail. Although he is in the St. Tammany Parish Jail, he is in DOC 
custody. 
8.  James LeBlanc is the Secretary of the DOC and its final policymaker. He has served 
in that role since 2008. He is appointed by the Louisiana governor and is the chief executive officer 
for the DOC. He formulates rules and regulations for the DOC, and he determines policy regarding 
management, personnel, and total operations for the agency. He oversees the DOCโs central office 
and its field unit staff, who are charged with carrying out the work of the agency and protecting the 
rights of all persons held in DOC custody. At all relevant times, Secretary LeBlanc has acted under 
color of law. He can be served at 504 Mayflower Street, Baton Rouge, LA 70802.  
9.  The Louisiana Department of Public Safety & Corrections (โDOCโ) oversees the 
custody and care of adults in its custody and includes adults under probation and parole supervision, 
pursuant to La. R.S. ยง 36:4. The domicile of the DOC and its divisions is the parish of East Baton 
Rouge, city of Baton Rouge, Louisiana, pursuant to R.S. 15:821.1.

II.  The DOC Has a Pattern and Practice of Overdetaining People in Its Custody 
16.  Mr. Giroirโs case is not an aberrationโon the contrary, his false imprisonment 
through overdetention is the standard practice of the DOCโa standard practice that Defendants 
have known about for at least eight years, yet have failed to change.

Case 3:21-cv-00108-JWD-SDJ     Document 46    04/27/22   Page 5 of 21
 
17.  Defendants have been aware of the problem of overdetention in Louisiana since at 
least 2012. 
18.  The DOC has no process in place for ensuring that persons entitled to immediate 
release upon sentencing are actually released upon sentencing, or any time promptly thereafter.  
19.  Instead, the DOC detains such people for weeks and even months with no idea 
whether it has a legal right to imprison them at all. For the DOC, such determinations are made in 
an unhurried process in which the agency (1) waits days or weeks for others to provide it with the 
personโs sentencing order, and then (2) waits weeks to actually examine that sentencing order and 
determine whether the DOC has the legal authority to continue to detain the person. During all that 
time, the person who should be freeโwhom a judge has already deemed eligible for immediate 
releaseโlanguishes behind bars. Thousands of people in Louisiana suffer this fate every year. 
20.  To make matters worse, the leadership of the DOC, including Secretary LeBlanc, 
have been acutely aware of this problem since at least 2012. And after making half-hearted efforts to 
mitigate the problem, they have essentially abandoned those efforts and have specifically endorsed 
overdetention as a normal practice. 
A.  The  DOC  Detains  Thousands  of  People Past Their Legal Release Dates 
Every Year  
21.  The DOC recognizes that a person who (1) has spent time in custody pretrial, (2) is 
given a sentence with credit for time served, and (3) has a sentence that is less than or equal to their 
period of pretrial custody is entitled to release on the day of their sentencing. See Ex. 4, Dep. of 
DOC 30(b)(6) Representative Angela Griffin (May 31, 2019) at 30-31. For example, a person who 
spent two months in jail awaiting sentencing, and is then sentenced to thirty days with credit for 
time served, is entitled to release on the day of his sentencing.  
22.  The DOC is responsible for a personโs overdetention from the day of sentencing, 
even if the person is not physically housed in a DOC facility.

III.  Rule 23(b)(2) 
80.  Class action status is appropriate because Defendants have acted or will act in the 
same  unconstitutional  manner  with  respect  to  all  Class  Members.  Defendants  unlawfully  and 
knowingly detain thousands of Louisianans past their legal release dates every year. 
81.  The Class therefore seeks declaratory and injunctive relief to enjoin Defendants from 
continuing to overdetain and falsely imprison people in their custody. Because the putative Class 
challenges Defendantsโ conduct as unconstitutional through declaratory and injunctive relief, which 
would apply the same relief to every Class Member, Rule 23(b)(2) certification is appropriate and 
necessary. 
82.  Injunctive  relief  compelling  Defendants  to  comply  with  Class  Membersโ 
constitutional rights will similarly protect each Class Member from being subjected to Defendantsโ 
unlawful  policies  and  practices.  A  declaration  and  injunction  stating  that  Defendants  cannot 
continue to detain people past their legal release dates would provide relief to every Class Member. 
Therefore, declaratory and injunctive relief with respect to the Class as a whole is appropriate.

85.  The  Due  Process  Clause  of  the  Fourteenth  Amendment  to  the  United  States 
Constitution is violated where a person remains incarcerated after the legal authority to hold that 
person has expired. See Douthit v. Jones, 619 F.2d 527, 532 (5th Cir. 1980). No privilege enables a 
jailor to detain a person beyond the period of that personโs lawful sentence. See Whirl v. Kern, 407 
16 

Case 3:21-cv-00108-JWD-SDJ     Document 46    04/27/22   Page 17 of 21
 
F.2d 781, 791 (5th Cir. 1968); see also Powell v. Barrett, 376 F. Supp. 2d 1340, 1351 (N.D. Ga. 2005) 
(detainee has constitutional right to be free from continued detention after it was or should have 
been known that he was entitled to release). 
86.  The DOCโs legal authority to detain Plaintiff Joel Giroir expired on the day of his 
sentencing, January 26, 2021. Yet pursuant to an unlawful standard practice that has existed for 
years, the DOC continues to detain Plaintiff. 
87.  The DOC is falsely imprisoning Plaintiff pursuant to a practice that has existed for 
years in which it waits weeks and even months to determine whether it has lawful authority to 
imprison persons who in fact were entitled to release on the day of their sentences. That practice is 
injuring the hundreds of members of the putative class, as described in this Complaint. 
88.  Secretary LeBlanc has been aware of this practice since at least 2012, but he has not 
attempted to stop it; instead, Defendants have attempted to normalize their own misconduct.  
89.  Secretary LeBlancโs failure to adopt a policy or policies to prevent overdetention is 
โdeliberately indifferentโ because โit is obvious that the likely consequences of not adopting a policy 
will be a deprivation of constitutional rights.โ Rhyne v. Henderson Cnty., 973 F.2d 386, 392 (5th Cir. 
1992). 
90.  In  failing  to  adopt  any  policy  to  prevent  predictable  overdetention,  Secretary 
LeBlanc acted with deliberate indifference. This is evidenced by the fact that every investigation into 
the matter since 2012 has shown that overdetention is a persistent and widespread problem in 
Louisiana, yet Secretary LeBlanc did not create any policy to attempt to remedy the problem. 
91.  Through his deliberate indifference, Secretary LeBlanc is depriving Mr. Giroir, and 
all Members of the putative Class he seeks to represent, of the fundamental right to liberty and 
violating their due process rights under the Fourteenth Amendment, causing the injuries described 
in this Complaint. 
17 

Case 3:21-cv-00108-JWD-SDJ     Document 46    04/27/22   Page 18 of 21
 
COUNT II 
Due Process under Article I, Section 2 of the Louisiana Constitution 
92.  Plaintiff repeats and re-alleges the preceding paragraphs as if fully set forth in this 
Count. 
93.  Plaintiff Joel Giroir brings this claim on his own behalf and on behalf of the putative 
Class against Defendants. 
94.  Article One, Section Two of the Louisiana Constitution of 1974 guarantees that 
โ[n]o person shall be deprived of life, liberty, or property, except by due process of law.โ  
95.  By reason of the same conduct that violates Plaintiffโs federal constitutional rights, 
Defendants violate Plaintiffโs state constitutional rights to liberty and due process, as well as the state 
constitutional rights of the putative class he seeks to represent, causing the injuries described in this 
Complaint. 
COUNT III 
False Imprisonment under State Law 
96.  Plaintiff repeats and re-alleges the preceding paragraphs as if fully set forth in this 
Count. 
97.  Plaintiff Joel Giroir brings this claim on his own behalf and on behalf of the putative 
Class against Defendants. 
98.  Defendants are committing the tort of false imprisonment against Plaintiff because 
the DOC is โrestrain[ing] [Plaintiff] against his will without a warrant or other statutory authority,โ 
Kyle v. City of New Orleans, 353 So.2d 969, 971 (La. 1977); see also Miller v. Desoto Regional Health Sys., 
128 So.3d 649, 655-56 (La. App. 3d Cir. 2013), beyond Plaintiffโs legal release date. By definition, 
the Class Members Plaintiff seeks to represent are also falsely imprisoned by Defendants because 
they  are,  or  will  be,  unlawfully  detained  beyond  their  legal  release  dates,  causing  the  injuries 
described in this Complaint. 
18 

Case 3:21-cv-00108-JWD-SDJ     Document 46    04/27/22   Page 19 of 21
 
COUNT IV 
State Law Negligence 
99.  Plaintiff repeats and re-alleges the preceding paragraphs as if fully set forth in this 
Count. 
100.  Plaintiff Joel Giroir brings this claim on his own behalf and on behalf of the putative 
Class against Defendants. 
101.  Defendants owe duties to avoid overdetention to persons in DOC custody, including 
Plaintiff and the members of the putative Class. Porter v. Epps, 659 F. 3d 440, 445 (5th Cir. 2011) (a 
jailor has โnot only the duty to protect a prisoner, but also the duty to effect his timely release.โ). 
102.  These duties are being breached by Defendantsโ acts and omissions, including the 
failure to timely release Plaintiff and the putative Class Members. 
103.  The  risks and harms that Defendants cause are within the scope of protection 
afforded by the duties Defendants owe to Plaintiff and to the putative Class Members. 
104.  As  a  result  of  Defendantsโ  acts  and omissions,  Plaintiff and the putative Class 
Members are suffering actual, foreseeable harm, as described in this Complaint. 
COUNT V 
State Law Intentional Infliction of Emotional Distress 
105.  Plaintiff repeats and re-alleges the preceding paragraphs as if fully set forth in this 
Count. 
106.  Defendants have acted intentionally or recklessly regarding the false imprisonment 
and overdetention of Mr. Giroir and the Members of the putative Class. 
107.  Defendantsโ conduct is extreme and outrageous, and it is rooted in an abuse of 
power and authority over the freedom of Mr. Giroir and the Members of the putative Class. 
19 

Case 3:21-cv-00108-JWD-SDJ     Document 46    04/27/22   Page 20 of 21
 
108.  Defendantsโ misconduct is causing severe emotional distress, induced by weeks and 
even months of caging in crowded, dangerous jails and prisons of persons who are legally entitled to 
be free.  
PRAYER FOR RELIEF 
Wherefore, Plaintiff Joel Giroir requests that this Court enter judgment in his favor, and in 
favor of the putative class he seeks to represent, against Defendants and order the following relief: 
(a) An order and judgment declaring that Defendantsโ practice of routinely allowing 
individuals to be incarcerated past their legal release dates violates Plaintiffโs 
rights under the United States Constitution as well as the state law rights of the 
class Plaintiff seeks to represent; 
 
(b) An  order  and  judgment  enjoining  Defendants  from  continuing  to  allow 
individuals  to  be  incarcerated  past  their  legal  release  dates  and  ordering 
Defendants to establish procedures to prevent all such overdetention; 
 
(c) An order and judgment requiring Defendants to calculate sentences and release 
as soon as reasonably feasible, and in no event longer than 48 hours after the 
person is sentenced, for all persons sentenced to the custody of the DOC who 
are eligible for immediate release upon sentencing; 
 
(d) An order and judgment ordering Defendants to release Plaintiff and all members 
of the class Plaintiff seeks to represent; 
 
(e) An order and judgment granting reasonable attorneysโ fees and costs pursuant to 
42 U.S.C. ยง 1988 and all other applicable laws; and  
 
(f)  Any other relief this Court deems proper. 
 
JURY DEMAND 
 
Pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 38, Plaintiff demands a trial by jury on all issues 
so triable. 
Respectfully submitted this 27th day of April, 2022. 
 
/s/ Mercedes Montagnes 
Mercedes Montagnes, La. Bar No. 33287

documents.title: Second Amended Class Action Complaint
documents.text:
Case 3:20-cv-00233-JWD-SDJ     Document 43    04/29/21   Page 1 of 25
 
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
MIDDLE DISTRICT OF LOUISIANA 
BRIAN  HUMPHREY,  JOEL  GIROIR,  and   
BRYANT  WHITE,  on  behalf  of  themselves  CIVIL  ACTION  NO.  3:20-cv-00233-JWD-
and all similarly situated individuals,    SDJ 
           
Plaintiff,  CLASS ACTION 
   
v.   
  JURY TRIAL DEMANDED 
JAMES LEBLANC,   
   
Defendant.   
 
 
SECOND AMENDED CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT1 
INTRODUCTION 
1.  For years now, the Louisiana Department of Public Safety & Corrections (โthe 
DOCโ) has been unlawfully and knowingly overdetaining thousands of Louisiana residents in its 
custody  every  year.  Defendant  James  LeBlanc,  Secretary  of  the  DOC,  has  known  about  this 
misconduct since at least 2012.2 Secretary LeBlanc has admitted that the DOC is โlegally boundโ to 
release people on time, and he has admitted that the DOCโs chronic, unlawful overdetention is a 
โbig problem.โ3 Yet Secretary LeBlanc has done little to fix the big problem. 
2.  By  overdetaining  Louisianans  as  a  matter  of  policy,  the  DOC  is  usurping  the 
sentencing authority that belongs to Louisianaโs judiciary. Many of these people are sentenced by a 
court or a parole board to โtime servedโ or an equivalent sentence or parole or probation revocation 
determination that legally entitles them to immediate release from the moment they are sentenced or 
have their parole or probation revoked. But they are not immediately released. Instead, as a standard 
practice,  the  DOC  drags  its  feet  computing  their  release  dates  and,  in  the  meantime,  simply 
 
1 Plaintiffs file this amendment pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 15(a)(2), with leave 
granted by the Court. See ECF 35.  
2 Ex. 1, Dep. of Secretary LeBlanc at 45, 48-49.  

Case 3:20-cv-00233-JWD-SDJ     Document 43    04/29/21   Page 2 of 25
 
continues to detain people who should be free and whom the DOC has no legal authority to 
imprison. Many are forced to sit for weeks or even months with no idea of when the DOC will get 
around  to  processing  their  paperwork  and  releasing  them.  The  DOC,  in  other  words,  falsely 
imprisons thousands of people every year, degrading lives and creating uncertainty and misery for 
families across the state.  
3.  Still, Secretary LeBlanc has not implemented any policy to ensure that the DOC 
stops overdetainingโand falsely imprisoningโLouisianans. Overdetention costs the state at least 
$2.8M per year,4 but Secretary LeBlanc has not attempted to reallocate that spending toward new 
measures to prevent the DOC from holding people past their legal release dates. Meanwhile, the 
DOC simply pretends that overdetention is an acceptable part of a personโs punishment, when by 
law it is not. 
4.  Named Plaintiffs Brian Humphrey, Joel Giroir, and Bryant White were victims of the 
DOCโs misconduct. They seek to represent a Class of all persons who have been remanded to the 
custody of the DOC since April 16, 2019 (pursuant to a criminal sentence or a parole or probation 
revocation), and who were entitled to release at the time they were remanded to the DOCโs custody, 
but who were released by the DOC more than 48 hours past the time that they were remanded. On 
behalf of the numerous people subject to this unlawful practice, the Named Plaintiffs seek to have 
each  putative  class  member  recover  the  damages  they  suffered  from  their  false  and  unlawful 
overdetention.  
JURISDICTION AND VENUE 
5.  This Court has original jurisdiction over Plaintiffsโ federal claims pursuant to 28 
U.S.C. ยงยง 1331 and 1343(a). It has jurisdiction over Plaintiffsโ state law claims pursuant to 28 U.S.C. 
 
3 Id. at 41. 
4 Ex. 2, DOC Grant Application at 4. 
2 

Case 3:20-cv-00233-JWD-SDJ     Document 43    04/29/21   Page 3 of 25
 
ยง  1367  because  those  claims  arise  from  the  same  events  and are  part  of  the  same  case  and 
controversy as the federal claims.  
6.  Venue is proper in this district under 28 U.S.C. ยง 1391 because Defendant resides in 
this judicial district, and because a substantial part of the events giving rise to Plaintiffsโ claims 
occurred in this judicial district. 
PARTIES 
7.  Plaintiff Brian Humphrey was eligible for immediate release upon his sentencing on 
April 16, 2019,5 but the DOC did not release him from custody until May 13, 2019,6 the day that the 
DOC finally computed his release date and found him eligible for immediate release.7 The DOC did 
not compute Mr. Humphreyโs release date or set him free until 17 days after the DOC received his 
paperwork from the Bossier Parish Sheriffโs Office on April 26, 2019, and 27 days after he was 
sentenced on April 16.8 
8.  Plaintiff Joel Giroir was eligible for immediate release upon his probation revocation 
and resentencing hearing on January 26, 2021. Instead he was detained for weeks beyond his legal 
release date and was not released until February 22, 2021. 
9.  Plaintiff Bryant White was eligible for immediate release from the Orleans Parish jail 
after pleading guilty on charges with credit for time served, on March 1, 2021, but instead was 
placed on a โparole holdโ for weeks and was not released until April 23, 2021. 
10.  Defendant James LeBlanc is the Secretary of the DOC and its final policymaker. He 
is sued in his individual capacity. He has served in that role since 2008. He is appointed by the 
Louisiana governor and is the chief executive officer for the DOC, which includes both prisons and 
the Board of Pardons and Parole. He formulates rules and regulations for the DOC, and he 
 
5 Ex. 3, Humphrey Sentencing Minutes at 2. 
6 Ex. 4, Humphrey Certificate of Release. 
7 Ex. 5, Humphrey Release Date Computation Information. 
3 

Case 3:20-cv-00233-JWD-SDJ     Document 43    04/29/21   Page 4 of 25
 
determines  policy  regarding  management,  personnel,  and  total  operations  for  the  agency.  He 
oversees the DOCโs central office and its field unit staff, who are charged with carrying out the work 
of the agency and protecting the rights of all persons held in DOC custody. Secretary LeBlanc was 
aware of and consciously disregarded a substantial risk of overdetention to the putative Class. He 
was aware of the overdetention problem but failed to exert the supervision necessary to end it. At all 
relevant times, Secretary LeBlanc has acted under color of law.  
FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS 
I.  Named Plaintiffs Were Overdetained for More than 48 Hours by the DOC after They 
Were Entitled to Immediate Release  
A.  Brian Humphrey 
11.  On April 16, 2019, the 26th Judicial District Court in Bossier Parish sentenced Mr. 
Humphrey to โ3 years hard labor in the Louisiana Department of Corrections.โ In issuing that 
sentence, however, the Court simultaneously gave Mr. Humphrey credit for the time he had already 
served in jail, and ordered further that the sentence should โsuspend all but time served.โ9 In other 
words, Mr. Humphreyโs sentencing judge gave him credit for the time he had served in jail, and 
otherwise suspended his sentence. Thus, as of the date of his sentencing, Mr. Humphrey had served 
his entire sentence. He should have been released immediately. 
12.  That did not happen. Instead, the Bossier Parish Sheriff took Mr. Humphrey back 
into the jail. Then, on April 18, 2019, Mr. Humphrey was transported to Webster โ Bayou Dorcheat 
Correctional Center Transitional Work Program, a DOC facility. There Mr. Humphrey, who by law 
should have been a free man, waited in prison for weeks, until the DOC got around to reviewing his 
papers and finally released him.  
 
8 Ex. 6, Facsimile Transmittal Sheet. 
9 Ex. 3, Humphrey Sentencing Minutes at 2. 
4 

Case 3:20-cv-00233-JWD-SDJ     Document 43    04/29/21   Page 5 of 25
 
13.  From the date of his sentencing on April 16, 2019, Mr. Humphrey was in the 
custody of the DOC. On information and belief, during the first ten days of Mr. Humphreyโs 
custody, the DOC made no attempt to determine whether it had any legal right to imprison him. 
14.  Then, on April 26, 2019, the Bossier Sheriffโs Office sent to the DOC paperwork 
that the Sheriff had received from the Clerk of Court of the 26th Judicial District. This paperwork 
contained a note that read โ3 years HC DOC all but time served suspended.โ10 Mr. Humphreyโs 
Uniform  Sentencing  Commitment  Order  notes  โ0โ  years,  โ0โ  months,  and  โ0โ  days  under 
โAmount of Time in DPS&C custody.โ11 Also on April 26, 2019, the Bossier Sheriffโs Office faxed 
14  pages  of  โpre-classโ  information  on  Mr.  Humphrey  to  the  Bayou  Dorcheat  Correctional 
Center,12 where Mr. Humphrey was being held in DOC custody. 
15.  This paperwork made plain that Mr. Humphrey should have been a free man already, 
and that the DOC had no right to detain him. But the DOC did not release him. Instead, with the 
paperwork in hand, the DOC waited more than two weeks to determine whether it had any 
authority to imprison Mr. Humphrey at all. 
16.  On May 13, 2019, the DOC completed Mr. Humphreyโs time computation, resulting 
in a calculation of 0 days.13 Mr. Humphreyโs โmust serveโ time was calculated to be -114 days.14 Any 
person whose โmust serveโ comes to a negative number is eligible for immediate release.15 
17.  That same day, May 13, 2019, the DOC issued a โCertificate of Releaseโ for Mr. 
Humphrey certifying his โCompletion of Sentence.โ16 
 
10 Ex. 7, Humphrey DOC Basic Information Interview for Local Jail Facilities. 
11 Ex. 8, Humphrey Uniform Sentencing Commitment Order. 
12 Ex. 6, Facsimile Transmittal Sheet. 
13 Ex. 5, Humphrey Release Date Computation Information. 
14 Ex. 9, Humphrey Time Computation and Jail Credits. 
15 Ex. 10, Dep. of DOC 30(b)(6) Representative Angela Griffin (Jan. 10, 2020) at 87. 
16 Ex. 4, Humphrey Certificate of Release. 
5 

Case 3:20-cv-00233-JWD-SDJ     Document 43    04/29/21   Page 6 of 25
 
18.  Mr. Humphrey was released from DOC custody on May 13, 2019, at 5:30 PM, 27 
days after he was entitled for immediate release upon his sentencing and 17 days after the DOC 
received his paperwork from the Bossier Sheriffโs Office. 
B.  Joel Giroir17 
19.  Joel Giroir is a 36-year-old man who was overdetained by the DOC in the St. 
Tammany Parish Jail.  
20.  Mr. Giroir was held on an attachment with no bond in case number 589-169 and 
held on a $5,000 bond in case number 589-855 in St. Tammany Parish Jail from January 30, 2018, to 
March 13, 2018. He was held with no bond on case numbers 589-855 and 589-169 from June 12, 
2018 until July 19, 2018. On July 19, 2018, he was sentenced to 90 days in DOC custody in lieu of 
revocation. He served 110 days in Concordia Parish Jail. He turned himself into St. Tammany Parish 
Jail on January 22, 2021, and was incarcerated there until his revocation hearing date on January 26, 
2021.  
21.  On  January  26,  2021,  Mr.  Giroir  had  a  probation  revocation  and  resentencing 
hearing. He was sentenced to one year in DOC custody.  
22.  Under  Louisianaโs  โgood  timeโ  law,  Mr.  Giroir  is  entitled  to  a  diminution  of 
sentence. La. Rev. Stat. ยง 15:571.3(B)(1)(a). Because of his good behavior and because he was not 
convicted of a crime of violence, he is only required to serve 35 percent of his one-year sentence, or 
128 days.  
23.  As of the date of his revocation and sentencing on January 26, 2021, Mr. Giroir had 
served at least 192 days in jail on his one-year sentence. Thus, on the date of his sentencing, he was 
eligible for immediate release.  
 
17  Ex. 18, Declaration of Joel Giroir. 
6 

Case 3:20-cv-00233-JWD-SDJ     Document 43    04/29/21   Page 7 of 25
 
24.  Mr. Giroir was not immediately released on January 26, 2021, even though he had 
already served at least 64 days beyond his sentence. Instead, he was held in the jail until February 22, 
2021. 
C.  Bryant White18 
25.  Bryant White was overdetained by the DOC in the Orleans Parish jail for more than 
seven weeks. 
26.  In 2013 Mr. White was sentenced on a criminal conviction, served time in prison, 
and was later released on parole.  
27.  On March 12, 2019, while he was on parole for the 2013 sentence, Mr. White was 
arrested in Orleans Parish and confined to the Orleans Parish jail. A parole hold was then placed on 
Mr. White, on April 4, 2019.  
28.  On March 1, 2021, while still in the custody of the Orleans Parish jail, Mr. White 
pleaded guilty to two felony charges stemming from the March 12, 2019 arrest, and was sentenced 
to 6 months and 23 months to run concurrently, with credit for the time he had served in the 
Orleans Parish jail since March 12, 2019.  
29.  By the time of his plea, Mr. White had served 697 days in jail since March 12, 2019. 
Under Louisianaโs โgood timeโ law, he was entitled to a diminution of the remainder of his 2013 
sentence for which the DOC had issued the parole hold. As such, under Louisianaโs sentencing laws, 
the DOC should have โrevokedโ his parole at the time of his March 1, 2021 plea, and, with credit 
for the 697 days he had served, he should have been released immediately. 
30.  Mr. White was not released on March 1, 2021, however. Instead, the DOC took 
more than seven weeks to revoke his parole, finally doing so on April 23, 2021. During that time Mr. 
White was imprisoned in the Orleans Parish jail by the DOC on the parole hold, even though the 
 
18 Ex. 19, Declaration of Bryant White. 
7 

Case 3:20-cv-00233-JWD-SDJ     Document 43    04/29/21   Page 8 of 25
 
DOC  lacked  legal authority  to  imprison  him  on  the  parole  hold  after  his  March  1  plea  and 
sentencing.  
II.  The DOC Has a Pattern and Practice of Overdetaining People in Its Custody 
31.  The  Named  Plaintiffsโ  cases  were  not  aberrationsโto  the  contrary,  their  false 
imprisonment through overdetention is the standard practice of the DOC, a standard practice that 
Defendant LeBlanc has known about for at least eight years, yet has failed to change.  
32.  The DOC has no process in place for ensuring that persons entitled to immediate 
release upon sentencing or parole or probation revocation are actually released on time, or any time 
quickly thereafter. Instead, the DOC detains such people for weeks and even months with no idea 
whether it has a legal right to imprison them at all. For the DOC, such determinations are made in 
an unhurried process in which the DOCโs central office responsible for computing time and issuing 
release instructions (1) waits days or weeks for others to provide it with the personโs sentencing or 
parole or probation revocation paperwork, and then (2) waits days or weeks to actually examine the 
paperwork and determine whether the DOC has the legal authority to detain the person. During all 
that time, the person who should be freeโwhom a judge or parole board has already deemed 
eligible for immediate releaseโlanguishes behind bars. Thousands of people in Louisiana suffer this 
fate every year. 
33.  To make matters worse, the leadership of the DOC, including Defendant LeBlanc, 
have been acutely aware of this problem since at least 2012. And after making half-hearted efforts to 
mitigate the problem, they have shifted instead to justify and normalize the false imprisonment of 
thousands of Louisianans every year. 
A.  The DOC Detains Thousands of People Past Their Legal Release Dates 
Every Year  
34.  The DOC recognizes that a person who (1) has spent time in custody pretrial, (2) is 
given a sentence with credit for time served, and (3) has a sentence that is less than or equal to their 
8 

Case 3:20-cv-00233-JWD-SDJ     Document 43    04/29/21   Page 9 of 25
 
period of pretrial custody is entitled to release on the day of their sentencing.19 For example, a 
person who spent two months in jail awaiting sentencing, and is then sentenced to thirty days with 
credit for time served, is entitled to release on the day of his sentencing.  
35.  The DOC is responsible for a personโs overdetention from the day of sentencing or 
parole or probation revocation, even if the person is not yet in a DOC facility. The DOC has 
conceded that a personโs โadmit dateโ to DOC custody is the date of that personโs sentencing,20 and 
the equivalent is true when a personโs parole or probation is revoked. Indeed, Secretary LeBlanc has 
explained that he is responsible for the inmates remanded โto the custody of the DOC,โ whether 
they are in โa state-run facility, a parish-run facility, or private-facility.โ21 
36.  Any person who is detained past their legal release date is overdetained. The DOC 
admits that it is โlegally bound to release inmates on their release date.โ22 Secretary LeBlanc has 
stated  that  he  first  learned  โthat  thousands  of  people  in  the  custody  of  the  Department  of 
Corrections for whatever reason were being held past their release dateโ in 2012.23 But every 
investigation into the matter since that time has confirmed that the problem continues; indeed it has 
even come to the attention of judges and legislators. 
37.  In 2012, a team of DOC staff performed a review of its time calculation processes, 
which revealed a widespread pattern of people being held past their legal release dates. Specifically, 
the investigation found that when the DOC calculated the release dates of inmates, 83% were 
eligible for โimmediate release . . . due to an earlier release date.โ24 The DOC learned through this 
investigation that it was overdetaining over 2,000 people each year, with an average of 71.69 
 
19 See Ex. 11, Dep. of DOC 30(b)(6) Representative Angela Griffin (May 31, 2019) at 30-31. 
20 Ex. 12, Dep. of DOC 30(b)(6) Representative Melanie Gueho at 53. 
21 Ex. 1, Dep. of Secretary LeBlanc at 13. 
22 Id. at 15. 
23 Id. at 48. 
24 Ex. 13, DOC Lean Six Sigma 2012 PreClassification at 4. 
9 

Case 3:20-cv-00233-JWD-SDJ     Document 43    04/29/21   Page 10 of 25
 
โoverdue daysโ per person who was overdetained.25 The DOC has admitted that this is โa lot of 
overdetention.โ26 
38.  The 2012 review found that some of the delay was caused by the time it took for the 
DOC to receive documents from the clerksโ and sheriffsโ offices, and the remainder was caused by 
the DOC itself taking an average of approximately 79 days to calculate release dates after it had the 
sentencing documents in hand.27 
39.  These 2012 findings should have set off alarm bells. Under Louisiana law, confining 
any person without legal authority amounts to false imprisonment. Under settled decisions by the 
United States Supreme Court, meanwhile, correctional facilities are allowed some time to ensure that 
an imprisoned personโs release is administratively proper, but in all events, it is presumptively 
unreasonable to imprison a person for more than 48 hours after they are entitled to release.28 The 
DOCโs imprisonment of people for months after they are entitled to release flagrantly violates the 
laws of Louisiana and the United States. 
40.  No such alarm was raised, however. After making their 2012 findings, the DOC did 
not  eliminate  or  even  meaningfully  mitigate  the  problem  of  overdetention.  Secretary  LeBlanc 
recently testified that he understood that โpeople [are still] being held [in DOC custody] an average 
of about two months past their release date.โ29 
41.  Indeed, five years after the 2012 investigation, in 2017, another internal investigation 
reported that the DOC had โan average of 200 inmates per month held an average of 49 days past 
 
25 Ex. 14, Dep. of DOC 30(b)(6) Representative Derek Ellis at 20. 
26 Ex. 15, Dep. of DOC 30(b)(6) Representative Angela Whittaker at 33. 
27 Id. (โQ. So this approximately 79-day number represents the DOCโs, to the best of its 
knowledge in 2012, about how long it was taking for documents to wait at the DOC to be 
calculated? A. Correct.โ). 
28 County of Riverside v. McLaughlin, 500 U.S. 44 (1991). 
29 Ex. 1, Dep. of Secretary LeBlanc at 45. 
10 

Case 3:20-cv-00233-JWD-SDJ     Document 43    04/29/21   Page 11 of 25
 
the end of their sentence.โ30  So many people were being overdetained under this practice that it 
cost the state โ$2.8M per year in housing costs alone.โ31 According to the DOC, this is โtaxpayer 
moneyโ that the โDOC should not have to spendโ on people whose sentences are complete.32 
42.  But the 2017 investigation did not fix things either. As recently as 2019, the DOC 
compiled a set of data and found that it had held at least 231 individuals past their legal release dates 
in a single month (February of 2019) for an average of 44 extra days.33 This suggests that over 2,000 
people per year are still being overdetained, seven years after the DOC first identified the problem. 
43.  The causes of this problem have been obvious since at least the 2012 investigation. 
That inquiry found that some of the delay was caused by the time it took for the DOC to receive 
documents from the clerksโ and sheriffsโ offices, and then, even after receiving the sentencing 
papers, the DOC was taking an average of approximately 79 additional days to complete the process 
of calculating sentences.34 For example, the DOC waits nearly 11 days on average to even begin 
calculating a personโs time once the paperwork is received from the sheriff or court clerk.35  
44.  As the DOCโs overdetention practices have continued, judges and state legislators 
have periodically reminded Secretary LeBlanc of the problem. 
45.  On January 20, 2015, Judge Mary Doggett of the 9th Judicial District Court sent an 
email that was forwarded to Secretary LeBlanc complaining that an individual had been held past his 
 
30 Ex. 14, Dep. of DOC 30(b)(6) Representative Derek Ellis at 38 (โQ. So itโs a true statement 
that the DOC found that in 2017 it had an average of 200 inmates per month held an average of 49 
days past the end of their sentence, correct? A. Yes.โ). 
31 Ex. 2, DOC Grant Application at 4. 
32 Ex. 14, Dep. of DOC 30(b)(6) Representative Derek Ellis at 35. 
33 See Ex. 16, Feb. Pull Doc.; see also Ex. X, Grant v. Gusman RFA Responses, RFA No. 76 (โIt is 
admitted that in February of 2019, 231 people were found to be held past the release date, with an 
average of 44 days waiting for release.โ). 
34 Ex. 15, Dep. of DOC 30(b)(6) Representative Angela Whittaker at 33. 
35 This number was obtained by calculating the average of the column โRECEIV TO COMPโ in 
Ex. 16, Feb. Pull Doc. The โRECEIV TO COMPโ column provides, for each individual listed, the 
number of days that passed between the DOC receiving the personโs paperwork and the DOC 
beginning the process of calculating the personโs time. 
11 

Case 3:20-cv-00233-JWD-SDJ     Document 43    04/29/21   Page 12 of 25
 
release date by nearly two months โin spite of several phone calls from Judge Randow for his 
release.โ36 
46.  On January 28, 2016, a state legislatorโs office emailed Secretary LeBlanc regarding 
an individual who had obtained โan order of immediate releaseโ more than two weeks prior, and 
was โstill being detained and has been given no explanation of the delay.โ37 
47.  On February 21, 2019, Secretary LeBlanc received an email from Judge Jules D. 
Edwards of the 15th Judicial District Court to which Judge Edwards had attached three articles 
about overdetention in Louisiana and information about a specific overdetained person. Judge 
Edwards added that โdefense attorneys in Lafayette are also complaining about the failure to timely 
release inmates from LPCC.โ Secretary LeBlancโs response indicated that he had read at least one of 
the articles.38 
B.  Secretary  LeBlanc  Has  Been  Deliberately  Indifferent  to  the  DOCโs 
Overdetention of Thousands of Louisianans 
48.  Multiple investigations since 2012, and repeated attempts to intervene by other 
branches of Louisiana government, have done little to change the DOCโs pattern of overdetention. 
The DOC has been content to tinker around the edges of the problem, while doing little to actually 
reduce or eliminate the mass false incarceration it is committing. 
49.  Upon learning of the scale of its overdetention problem in 2012, the DOC did not 
set a goal of eliminating the problem. Rather, it set a goal to โ[r]educe the percentage of Immediate 
 
36 Ex. 17, Secretary LeBlanc Emails 3-4 (Email from Mary Lauve Doggett, District Judge, 9th 
JDC, to Cole Gralapp, District Administrator, Probation and Parole (Jan. 20, 2015, 4:48 PM) 
(forwarded to James LeBlanc Jan. 23, 2015, 1:54 PM)). 
37 Id. at 10 (Email from the office of Chris Hazel, State Representative, House District No. 27, to 
James LeBlanc, Secretary, DOC (Jan. 28, 2016, 9:44 AM)). 
38 Id. at 1-2 (Email from Jules D. Edwards III, District Judge, 15th JDC, to Rhett Covington, 
Assistant Secretary, DOC (forwarded to James LeBlanc Feb. 24, 2019, 6:14 PM)). 
12 

Case 3:20-cv-00233-JWD-SDJ     Document 43    04/29/21   Page 13 of 25
 
Releases by 80% (from 2252 to 450/yr)โ and to โ[r]educe the average number of days per case for 
immediate releases from 71.69 days (non CTRP) to 31 days.โ39 
50.  After learning that the DOC was still detaining people an average of about two 
months past their legal release dates even with the intervention resulting from the 2012 review in 
place, Secretary LeBlanc did not fire anyone. He did not demote anyone. He did not dock anyoneโs 
pay. He did not even reprimand anyone.40 He did not take any supervisory action to prevent his 
agency from continuing to detain people past their legal release dates. 
51.  Since that time, Secretary LeBlanc has not consulted with the heads of other statesโ 
departments of corrections about how they ensure that people are not detained past their legal 
release dates, aside from looking at some of the software that other states use.41 
52.  Secretary LeBlanc has suggested that overdetention might be somewhat lessened in 
Louisiana if the DOC were to go and pick up the paperwork necessary to process release dates 
rather than waiting for sheriffs and clerks to deliver it,42 but the DOC has never implemented that 
strategy under Secretary LeBlancโs leadership. Likewise the DOCโs central office waits days to 
receive parole or probation revocation paperwork from its own parole board in order to begin 
calculating parole or probation revocation release times. 
53.  Secretary LeBlanc has failed to adopt a policy proposed by a legislative auditor that 
would impose a deadline on sheriffs to submit pre-classification packets to the DOC, despite his 
 
39 Ex. 13, DOC Lean Six Sigma 2012 PreClassification at 5. The DOC estimated that if it could 
achieve these goals of reducing the percentage of overdetained people by 80% and reducing the 
average number of days of overdetention per person to 31 days, it could save the state $3.7 million 
per year. Id. at 19. 
40 Ex. 1, Dep. of Secretary LeBlanc at 48-49. 
41 Id. at 103-04. 
42 Id. at 80, 100-01. 
13 

Case 3:20-cv-00233-JWD-SDJ     Document 43    04/29/21   Page 14 of 25
 
own admission that โthereโs no reason why [the DOC] couldnโtโ adopt such a policy and that he is 
โnot sure why we donโt, to be honest,โ and โwe could certainly, at least, make an attempt.โ43 
54.  Secretary LeBlanc has not adopted any policy for the DOC requiring the immediate 
calculation of sentences or parole revocation release dates; instead, he has allowed these dates to be 
calculated in an ad hoc manner after the DOC central office receives the relevant paperwork. 
55.  Further,  the  DOC  has  declined  help  when  offered.  For  example,  in  2019,  the 
executive director of the Louisiana Clerks of Court Association, Debbie Hudnall, had a series of 
meetings with the DOC and Secretary LeBlanc. Ms. Hudnall suggested that, to speed things up, the 
Clerks of Court could begin emailing sentencing documents to the DOC. The DOC declined, 
claiming that they โdonโt have the capability of receiving that.โ44 
56.  Aside from the specific investigations in 2012, 2017, and 2019, the DOC does not 
even keep a record or count of individuals who have been overdetained.45 
57.  Shockingly, the DOC has tried to frame overdetention as a component of a personโs 
sentence, stating that a personโs โsentence continuesโ past the legal release date ordered by a judge 
โuntil [the DOC does the personโs] time comp[utation] and release[s] him.โ46  
58.  Indeed, the DOC has endorsed overdetention as a matter of policy.  
 
43 See Crittindon v. Gusman, No. 3:17-cv-00512-SDD-EWD at 26 (M.D. La., Apr. 13, 2020) (order 
denying motions for summary judgment) (โ[B]oth Secretary LeBlanc and Defendant Stagg testified 
in their depositions that they were familiar with a proposal by the legislative auditor that such a 
deadline be implemented, and both men expressed approval for the idea. In fact, when Secretary 
LeBlanc was asked at his deposition if it has โever been considered to include a timeframe for the 
submission of these materials to DOC,โ he responded: โNot that Iโm aware of, but thereโs no 
reason why we couldnโt. I mean, Iโm not sure why we donโt, to be honest with you.โ Secretary 
LeBlanc added: โIโm not sure that we could enforce it to begin with, but we could certainly, at least, 
make an attempt.โโ) (emphasis in original). 
44 Testimony of Debbie Hudnall, Louisiana House of Representatives, Judiciary Committee, Jan. 
15, 2020, at 1:03:35, Available at 
http://house.louisiana.gov/H_Video/VideoArchivePlayer.aspx?v=house/2019/dec/1212_19_J
U. 
45 See Ex. 11, Dep. of DOC 30(b)(6) Representative Angela Griffin (May 31, 2019) at 29. 
46 Ex. 10, Dep. of DOC 30(b)(6) Representative Angela Griffin (Jan. 10, 2020) at 36-39. 
14 

Case 3:20-cv-00233-JWD-SDJ     Document 43    04/29/21   Page 15 of 25
 
59.  For example, at least as late as May 2019, the DOC websiteโs โFrequently Asked 
Questionsโ page stated, โIf a person has recently been sentenced to DOC custody, it can take up to 
12 weeks to calculate a date as the Department has to receive official paperwork from the sentencing 
court in order to calculate the offenderโs release date.โ The DOC has since removed the reference to 
taking โup to 12 weeks to calculate a date,โ a timeframe even Secretary LeBlanc conceded was 
โridiculousโ and โabsurd.โ47 
60.  The DOC also included an audio statement in its voicemail recording saying that it 
โtakes at least 90 days after sentencingโ for the department to calculate a personโs time. This 
statement was finally removed from the voicemail recording in or around February or March of 
2019.48   
61.  These voicemail and website statements reveal the scope of the DOCโs misconduct; 
their purpose was to discourage family members from โinundat[ing]โ the DOC with questions about 
when their loved onesโwho had been told by a judge that they were free to rejoin their familiesโ
would actually be released.49 
62.  Named Plaintiffs are among the thousands of people who have been wrongfully 
imprisoned as a result of Secretary LeBlancโs demonstrated indifference to the DOCโs unlawful 
conduct. 
CLASS ACTION ALLEGATIONS 
63.  Named Plaintiffs bring this action, on behalf of themselves and all others similarly 
situated, to assert the claims alleged in this Complaint on a common basis. 
64.  This action is brought and may properly be maintained as a class action pursuant to 
Rule 23(b)(3) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, because the questions of law or fact common 
 
47 Ex. 1, Dep. of Secretary LeBlanc at 88-90. 
48 See Ex. 14, Dep. of DOC 30(b)(6) Representative Derek Ellis at 12-13. 
15 

Case 3:20-cv-00233-JWD-SDJ     Document 43    04/29/21   Page 16 of 25
 
to proposed class members predominate over any questions affecting only individual members, and 
a class action is superior to other available methods for fairly and efficiently adjudicating this 
controversy. 
I.  The Plaintiff Class 
65.  Named Plaintiffs propose a class defined as: all persons who have been remanded to 
the custody of the DOC since April 16, 2019, and who were entitled to release at the time of their 
remand (either pursuant to sentencing or parole or probation revocation), but who were released by 
the DOC more than 48 hours past the time that they were remanded to the DOCโs custody. The 
Class seeks to recover damages for the injuries caused to each class member by this overdetention 
and false imprisonment. 
II.  Rule 23(a) 
66.  The proposed class satisfies the numerosity, commonality, typicality, and adequacy 
requirements of Rule 23(a). 
A.  Numerosity โ Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a)(1) 
67.  The Class is so numerous that joinder of all members is impracticable. The most 
recent overdetention data from the DOC (from February of 2019) shows that over 200 individuals 
were overdetained in a single month, suggesting that the DOC overdetains over 2,000 individuals 
over the course of a year. This 2019 count was consistent with data from 2017, which showed that 
the DOC had โan average of 200 inmates per month held . . . past the end of their sentence.โ50 
Upon information and belief, the DOC has not implemented any major changes that might have 
 
49  See  Ex.  1,  Dep.  of  Secretary  LeBlanc  at  89;  see  also  Ex.  14,  Dep.  of  DOC  30(b)(6) 
Representative Derek Ellis at 18. 
50 Ex. 14, Dep. of DOC 30(b)(6) Representative Derek Ellis at 38 (โQ. So itโs a true statement 
that the DOC found that in 2017 it had an average of 200 inmates per month held an average of 49 
days past the end of their sentence, correct? A. Yes.โ). 
16 

Case 3:20-cv-00233-JWD-SDJ     Document 43    04/29/21   Page 17 of 25
 
significantly mitigated the rate of overdetention that was captured in the February 2019 snapshot. 
Plaintiffs therefore estimate a class size of over 2,000 members. 
B.  Commonality โ Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a)(2) 
68.  All members of the proposed Class are subject to the same systemic unconstitutional 
policies, acts, and omissions on the part of Defendant described in this Complaint, and all have 
suffered or will suffer violations of their constitutional rights and their rights under state law as a 
result of the DOCโs pattern and practice of overdetaining people in its custody. 
69.  There are questions of law and fact common to the members of the class. 
70.  Questions of law that are common to all members of the class include, but are not 
limited to: 
โข  Whether the DOC had, or has, the legal authority to hold class members past their 
sentencing or parole or probation revocation dates under the United States 
Constitution; 
โข  Whether Class Members had, or have, a liberty interest in their immediate release 
upon sentencing or parole or probation revocation under the United States 
Constitution; 
โข  Whether Defendantโs failure to adopt a policy or policies to mitigate overdetention 
constitutes deliberate indifference; 
โข  Whether the DOC had, or has, the legal authority to hold class members past their 
sentencing or parole or probation revocation dates under the Louisiana Constitution; 
โข  Whether Class Members had, or have, a liberty interest in their immediate release 
upon sentencing or parole or probation revocation under the Louisiana Constitution; 
and 
โข  Whether the DOCโs detention of Class Members past their legal release dates 
constitutes false imprisonment under state law.  
 
71.  Questions of fact that are common to all members of the class include, but are not 
limited to: 
โข  Whether the DOC has a pattern of overdetaining people in its custody; 
โข  Whether Defendant is aware of the DOCโs pattern of overdetaining people;  
โข  Whether the DOC is responsible for people sentenced to DOC custody from the 
day they are sentenced; and 
โข  Whether Defendant failed to adopt a policy or policies to mitigate overdetention. 
 
17 

Case 3:20-cv-00233-JWD-SDJ     Document 43    04/29/21   Page 18 of 25
 
72.  Defendant is expected to raise common defenses to these claims, including denying 
that his actions violate the law. 
C.  Typicality โ Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a)(3) 
73.  Named Plaintiffsโ claims are typical of those of the Class, as their claims arise from 
the same policies, practices, or courses of conduct as those of the Class, and their claims are based 
on the same theories of law as the Classโs claims. Named Plaintiffs were eligible for immediate 
release upon their sentencing or parole or probation revocation, and the DOC held them in custody 
past that date. Named Representatives are therefore typical of the putative Class, and they suffered 
the same injury of overdetention described in this Complaint.  
D.  Adequacy โ Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a)(4) 
74.  Named Plaintiffs are adequate representatives of the Class because their interests in 
the vindication of the legal claims that they raise are entirely aligned with the interests of the other 
Class Members, who each have the same basic constitutional claims. Named Plaintiffs are members 
of the Class, and their interests coincide with, and are not antagonistic to, those of the other Class 
Members. 
75.  There are no known conflicts of interest among Class Members, all of whom have a 
similar interest in vindicating their constitutional rights. 
76.  Plaintiffs are represented by attorneys from the Promise of Justice Initiative, Loevy 
and Loevy, and Most & Associates, who have experience in litigating complex civil rights matters 
related to prisonersโ rights in federal court and extensive knowledge of both the details of the DOC 
and the relevant constitutional and statutory law. Most & Associates has litigated a number of 
individual overdetention cases in Louisiana. 
77.  Class counsel have a detailed understanding of local law and practices as they relate 
to federal constitutional requirements. 
18 

Case 3:20-cv-00233-JWD-SDJ     Document 43    04/29/21   Page 19 of 25
 
III.  Rule 23(b)(3) 
78.  Class action status is appropriate because the questions of law or fact common to 
Class Members predominate over any questions affecting only individual members, and a class 
action is superior to other available methods for fairly and efficiently adjudicating this controversy. 
79.  The question of Defendantโs longstanding indifference to policies that result in mass 
overdetention, and the mass overdetention that results from this indifference, predominates over 
any individualized issues related to the claims of individual Class Members. The issue of Defendantโs 
liability is common across the Class and will predominate over any unique or personal issues. 
80.  A class action is the superior form of adjudication of the claims alleged in this 
Complaint because most of the proposed Class Membersโ claims are negative value suits; for many 
Members of the putative Class, the damages at stake are too slight to repay the cost of an individual 
suit. Class Membersโ interests in individually controlling separate actions against Defendant for their 
overdetention is therefore low. Moreover, no unusual difficulties are likely to be encountered in the 
management of this class action. 
81.  Even  if  Class  Members  could  afford  to  litigate  their  claims  individually, 
individualized litigation creates a potential for inconsistent or contradictory judgments and increases 
delay and expense to all parties and to the courts. By contrast, the class action device presents far 
fewer management difficulties and provides the benefits of a single adjudication, economy of scale, 
and comprehensive supervision by a single court. 
CLAIMS FOR RELIEF 
COUNT I 
42 U.S.C. ยง 1983 
82.  Named Plaintiffs repeat and re-allege the preceding paragraphs as if fully set forth in 
this Count. 
19 

Case 3:20-cv-00233-JWD-SDJ     Document 43    04/29/21   Page 20 of 25
 
83.  Named Plaintiffs bring this claim on their own behalf and on behalf of the putative 
Class against Defendant. 
84.  The  Due  Process  Clause  of  the  Fourteenth  Amendment  to  the  United  States 
Constitution is violated where a person remains incarcerated after the legal authority to hold that 
person has expired.51 No privilege enables a jailor to detain a person beyond the period of that 
personโs lawful sentence.52 
85.  The DOCโs legal authority to detain Named Plaintiffs expired on the day they were 
sentenced or had their parole or probation revoked. Yet pursuant to an unlawful, standard practice 
that has existed for years, the DOC nevertheless continued detaining Named Plaintiffs for well over 
48 hours before attempting to determine whether it had any legal authority to imprison them. 
86.  The DOC falsely imprisoned Named Plaintiffs pursuant to a practice that has existed 
for years in which it waits weeks and even months to determine whether it has lawful authority to 
imprison persons who in fact were entitled to release on the day of their sentences or parole or 
probation revocations. That practice injured the thousands of members of the putative class, as 
described in this Complaint. 
87.  Defendant LeBlanc has been aware of this practice since at least 2012, but he has not 
attempted to stop it; instead the agency Defendant oversees has attempted to normalize its own 
misconduct.  
88.  Secretary LeBlancโs failure to adopt a policy or policies to prevent overdetention is 
โdeliberately indifferentโ because โit is obvious that the likely consequences of not adopting a policy 
will be a deprivation of constitutional rights.โ53 
 
51 See Douthit v. Jones, 619 F.2d 527, 532 (5th Cir. 1980). 
52 See Whirl v. Kern, 407 F.2d 781, 791 (5th Cir. 1968); see also Powell v. Barrett, 376 F. Supp. 2d 
1340, 1351 (N.D. Ga. 2005) (detainee has constitutional right to be free from continued detention 
after it was or should have been known that he was entitled to release). 
53 Rhyne v. Henderson Cnty., 973 F.2d 386, 392 (5th Cir. 1992). 
20 

Case 3:20-cv-00233-JWD-SDJ     Document 43    04/29/21   Page 21 of 25
 
89.  In failing to adopt any policy to prevent predictable overdetention, Secretary LeBlanc 
acted with deliberate indifference. This is evidenced by the fact that every investigation into the 
matter  since  2012  has  shown  that  overdetention  is  a  persistent  and  widespread  problem  in 
Louisiana, yet Secretary LeBlanc did not create any policy to attempt to remedy the problem. 
90.  Through his deliberate indifference, Secretary LeBlanc deprived Named Plaintiffs, 
and all Members of the putative Class they seek to represent, of the fundamental right to liberty and 
violated their due process rights under the Fourteenth Amendment, causing the injuries described in 
this Complaint. 
COUNT II 
Due Process under Article I, Section 2 of the Louisiana Constitution 
91.  Named Plaintiffs repeat and re-allege the preceding paragraphs as if fully set forth in 
this Count. 
92.  Named Plaintiffs bring this claim on their own behalf and on behalf of the putative 
Class against Defendant. 
93.  Article One, Section Two of the Louisiana Constitution of 1974 guarantees that 
โ[n]o person shall be deprived of life, liberty, or property, except by due process of law.โ  
94.  By reason of the same conduct that violated Named Plaintiffsโ federal constitutional 
rights, Defendant violated Named Plaintiffsโ state constitutional rights to liberty and due process, as 
well as the state constitutional rights of the putative class he seeks to represent, causing the injuries 
described in this Complaint. 
COUNT III 
False Imprisonment under State Law 
95.  Named Plaintiffs repeat and re-allege the preceding paragraphs as if fully set forth in 
this Count. 
21 

Case 3:20-cv-00233-JWD-SDJ     Document 43    04/29/21   Page 22 of 25
 
96.  Named Plaintiffs bring this claim on their own behalf and on behalf of the putative 
Class against Defendant. 
97.  Defendant committed the tort of false imprisonment against Named Plaintiffs when 
the DOC โrestrain[ed] [Named Plaintiffs] against [their] will without a warrant or other statutory 
authorityโ54 for multiple days beyond Named Plaintiffsโ legal release dates. By definition, the Class 
Members Named Plaintiffs seek to represent were also falsely imprisoned by Defendant when they 
were unlawfully detained beyond their legal release dates, causing the injuries described in this 
Complaint. 
COUNT IV 
State Law Negligence 
98.  Named Plaintiffs repeat and re-allege the preceding paragraphs as if fully set forth in 
this Count. 
99.  Named Plaintiffs bring this claim on their own behalf and on behalf of the putative 
Class against Defendant. 
100.  Defendant owes duties to avoid overdetention to persons in DOC custody, including 
Named Plaintiffs and the members of the putative Class.55 
101.  These duties were breached by Defendantโs acts and omissions, including the failure 
to timely release Named Plaintiffs and the putative Class Members. 
102.  The risks and harms that Defendant caused were within the scope of protection 
afforded by the duties he owed to Named Plaintiffs and to the putative Class Members. 
103.  As a result of Defendantโs acts and omissions, Named Plaintiffs and the putative 
Class Members suffered actual, foreseeable harm, as described in this Complaint. 
 
54 Kyle v. City of New Orleans, 353 So.2d 969, 971 (La. 1977); see also Miller v. Desoto Regional Health 
Sys., 128 So.3d 649, 655-56 (La. App. 3d Cir. 2013). 
55 Porter v. Epps, 659 F. 3d 440, 445 (5th Cir. 2011) (a jailor has โnot only the duty to protect a 
prisoner, but also the duty to effect his timely release.โ). 
22 

Case 3:20-cv-00233-JWD-SDJ     Document 43    04/29/21   Page 23 of 25
 
COUNT V 
State Law Intentional Infliction of Emotional Distress 
104.  Named Plaintiffs repeat and re-allege the preceding paragraphs as if fully set forth in 
this Count. 
105.  Named Plaintiffs bring this claim on their own behalf and on behalf of the putative 
Class against Defendant. 
106.  Defendant  Leblanc  has  acted  intentionally  or  recklessly  regarding  the  false 
imprisonment and overdetention of Named Plaintiffs and the Members of the putative Class. 
107.  Defendantโs conduct has been extreme and outrageous, and it has been rooted in an 
abuse of power and authority over the freedom of Named Plaintiffs and the Members of the 
putative Class. 
108.  Defendantโs misconduct has caused severe emotional distress, induced by weeks and 
even months of caging in crowded, dangerous jails and prisons of persons who were legally entitled 
to be free.  
PRAYER FOR RELIEF 
Wherefore, Named Plaintiffs request that this Court enter judgment in their favor, and in 
favor of the putative class they seek to represent, against Defendant James LeBlanc and order the 
following relief: 
(a) An order and judgment awarding compensatory and punitive damages to Named 
Plaintiffs and to the members of the putative class whom Named Plaintiffs seek 
to represent; 
 
(b) An order and judgment granting reasonable attorneysโ fees and costs pursuant to 
42 U.S.C. ยง 1988; and  
 
(c) Any other relief this Court deems proper. 
 
23 

Case 3:20-cv-00233-JWD-SDJ     Document 43    04/29/21   Page 24 of 25
 
JURY DEMAND 
 
Pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 38, Plaintiffs demand a trial by jury on 
all issues so triable. 
 
Respectfully submitted this 29th day of April, 2021. 
 
/s/ Mercedes Montagnes 
Mercedes Montagnes, La. Bar No. 33287

Attorneys for Plaintiffs

Case 3:20-cv-00233-JWD-SDJ     Document 43    04/29/21   Page 25 of 25

  I, Stephen H. Weil, an attorney, hereby certify that on April 29, 2021, I caused a copy of the 
foregoing to be filed with the Courtโs CM/ECF system, which will serve a copy of this document on

documents.text:
Case 3:20-cv-00233-JWD-SDJ     Document 1    04/15/20   Page 1 of 21
 
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
MIDDLE DISTRICT OF LOUISIANA 
BRIAN  HUMPHREY,  on  behalf  of  himself   
and all similarly situated individuals,   
          CIVIL ACTION NO.  
Plaintiff,   
  CLASS ACTION 
v.   
   
JAMES LEBLANC, in his official capacity as  JURY TRIAL DEMANDED 
Secretary  of  the  Louisiana  Department  of   
Public Safety & Corrections,   
   
Defendant. 
 
 
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT 
INTRODUCTION 
1.  For years now, the Louisiana Department of Public Safety & Corrections (โthe 
DOCโ) has been unlawfully and knowingly overdetaining thousands of Louisiana residents in its 
custody  every  year.  Defendant  James  LeBlanc,  Secretary  of  the  DOC,  has  known  about  this 
misconduct since at least 2012.1 Secretary LeBlanc has admitted that the DOC is โlegally boundโ to 
release people on time, and he has admitted that the DOCโs chronic, unlawful overdetention is a 
โbig problem.โ2 Yet Secretary LeBlanc has done little to fix the big problem. 
2.  By overdetaining Louisianans as a matter of policy, the DOC is essentially usurping 
the sentencing authority that rightfully belongs to the judiciary. Many of these people are sentenced 
by a court to โtime servedโ or an equivalent sentence that legally entitles them to immediate release 
from the moment they are sentenced. But they are not immediately released. Instead, as a standard 
practice, the DOC delays computation of release dates and, in the meantime, simply continues to 
detain people who should be free. Many are forced to sit for weeks or even months with no idea of 
 
1 Ex. 1, Dep. of Secretary LeBlanc at 45, 48-49.  
2 Id. at 41. 

Case 3:20-cv-00233-JWD-SDJ     Document 1    04/15/20   Page 2 of 21
 
when the DOC will get around to processing their paperwork and releasing them. The DOC, in

II.  The DOC Has a Pattern and Practice of Overdetaining People in Its Custody 
17.  Mr. Humphreyโs case was not an aberrationโto the contrary, his false imprisonment 
through overdetention is the standard practice of the DOC, a standard practice that Defendant 
LeBlanc has known about for at least eight years, yet has failed to change.  
18.  The DOC has no process in place for ensuring that persons entitled to immediate 
release  upon  sentencing  are  actually  released  upon  sentencing,  or  any  time  quickly  thereafter. 
Instead, the DOC detains such people for weeks and even months with no idea whether it has a 
legal right to imprison them at all. For the DOC, such determinations are made in an unhurried 
process in which the agency (1) waits days or weeks for others to provide it with the personโs 
sentencing order, and then (2) waits weeks to actually examine that sentencing order and determine 
whether the DOC has the legal authority to detain the person. During all that time, the person who

A.  The  DOC  Detains  Thousands  of  People  Past  Their  Legal  Release  Dates 
Every Year  
20.  The DOC recognizes that a person who (1) has spent time in custody pretrial, (2) is 
given a sentence with credit for time served, and (3) has a sentence that is less than or equal to their 
period of pretrial custody is entitled to release on the day of their sentencing.16 For example, a 
person who spent two months in jail awaiting sentencing, and is then sentenced to thirty days with 
credit for time served, is entitled to release on the day of his sentencing.  
21.  The DOC is responsible for a personโs overdetention from the day of sentencing, 
even if the person is not yet in a DOC facility. The DOC has conceded that a personโs โadmit dateโ 
to DOC custody is the date of that personโs sentencing.17  Indeed, Secretary LeBlanc has explained 
that he is โresponsible for the inmates sentenced to the custody of the DOC,โ whether they are in 
โa state-run facility, a parish-run facility, or private-facility.โ18 
22.  Any person who is detained past his or her legal release date is overdetained. The 
DOC admits that it is โlegally bound to release inmates on their release date.โ19  Secretary LeBlanc 
has stated that he first learned โthat thousands of people in the custody of the Department of

23.  In 2012, a team of DOC staff performed a review of its time calculation processes, 
which revealed a widespread pattern of people being held past their legal release dates. Specifically, 
the investigation found that when the DOC calculated the release dates of inmates, 83% were 
eligible for โimmediate release . . . due to an earlier release date.โ21 The DOC learned through this 
investigation that it was overdetaining over 2,000 people each year, with an average of 71.69 
โoverdue daysโ per person who was overdetained.22 The DOC has admitted that this is โa lot of 
overdetention.โ23 
24.  The 2012 review found that some of the delay was caused by the time it took for the 
DOC to receive documents from the clerksโ and sheriffsโ offices, and the remainder was caused by 
the DOC itself taking an average of approximately 79 days to calculate sentences after it had the 
sentencing documents in hand.24 
25.  These 2012 findings should have set off alarm bells. Under Louisiana law, confining 
any person without legal authority amounts to false imprisonment. Under settled decisions by the 
United States Supreme Court, meanwhile, correctional facilities are allowed some time to ensure that 
an imprisoned personโs release is administratively proper, but in all events, it is presumptively 
unreasonable to imprison a person for more than 48 hours after they are entitled to release.25 The

CLASS ACTION ALLEGATIONS 
49.  Named Plaintiff Brian Humphrey brings this action, on behalf of himself and all 
others similarly situated, to assert the claims alleged in this Complaint on a common basis. 
50.  This action is brought and may properly be maintained as a class action pursuant to 
Rule 23(b)(3) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, because the questions of law or fact common 
to proposed class members predominate over any questions affecting only individual members, and 
a class action is superior to other available methods for fairly and efficiently adjudicating this 
controversy. 
I.  The Plaintiff Class 
51.  Named Plaintiff proposes a class defined as: all persons who have been sentenced to 
the custody of the DOC since April 16, 2019, and who were entitled to release at the time of their 
sentencing, but who were released by the DOC more than 48 hours past the time that they were 
sentenced. The Class seeks to recover damages for the injuries caused to each class member by this 
overdetention and false imprisonment. 
II.  Rule 23(a) 
52.  The proposed class satisfies the numerosity, commonality, typicality, and adequacy 
requirements of Rule 23(a). 
A.  Numerosity โ Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a)(1) 
53.  The Class is so numerous that joinder of all members is impracticable. The most 
recent overdetention data from the DOC (from February of 2019) shows that over 200 individuals 
were overdetained in a single month, suggesting that the DOC overdetains over 2,000 individuals 
over the course of a year. This 2019 count was consistent with data from 2017, which showed that 
13 

Case 3:20-cv-00233-JWD-SDJ     Document 1    04/15/20   Page 14 of 21
 
the DOC had โan average of 200 inmates per month held . . . past the end of their sentence.โ47 
Upon information and belief, the DOC has not implemented any major changes that might have 
significantly mitigated the rate of overdetention that was captured in the February 2019 snapshot. 
Plaintiff therefore estimates a class size of over 2,000 members. 
B.  Commonality โ Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a)(2) 
54.  All members of the proposed Class are subject to the same systemic unconstitutional 
policies, acts, and omissions on the part of Defendant described in this Complaint, and all have

55.  There are questions of law and fact common to the members of the class.
